index.text: You are about to play a game based on factual reports about the labor conditions in China. It contains report about HEG technologies by China Labour Watch and the BBC report on Pegatron in China. Your decisions in the game will not only influence your story, but also your energy level and the money you have.

a1.text: Start

start1.text: Your name is Mei. In order to support your family you have decided to move to Huizhou in the Guangdong province- a city in southern China which has seen its population grow from a mere 300,000 in 1990 to over 1.8 million today supported by its well-known technology sector.

a1.text: Your family purchased your bus ticket and hand you 400 &yen for the first few days so you can go to work and send some money back home.

start2.text: After you rent a room for 250 ¥ you hear that one of the factories is hiring workers aged 16 to 30. Since you meet these qualifications, you decide to apply. You just have to fill in a form and decide:

a1.text: You don't wait for the call and just go home.

a2.text: You wait for them to call back.

goinghome.text: You return to your hometown without a job and you spent all the money your parents lent you to find a job. What are you going to do now?

contract1.text: You are called back and invited to have a training session. You are shown circuit boards that the factory produces for two big companies. The job seems very exhausting, especially because you are required to stand on your feet all day long.

a1.text: You decide to start working there.

test.text: The introductory training lasts three days and concludes with a short exam.

a1.text: You pass.

contract2.text: It's time to sign the employment contract. You and a dozen of your new possible colleagues meet with one of the plant managers. You barely have time to skim through the contract before being asked to sign  multiple pages.

a1.text: You find this unacceptable! You don't sign and go back home.

a2.text: You don't really have a choice but to sign in order to support your family.

goinghome2.text: You are back home without money or a job. So what do you do now?

id.text: The manager asks you for your ID. You feel very uncomfortable handing it over to someone else, but they insist on it. You know they are probably not going to give it back to you until you resign.

a1.text: You give them your ID anyway. You really need the job.

a2.text: You keep it and decide to leave as this makes you uncomfortable.

dorms.text: Your colleague Li Yan shows you the way to your dormitory. She explains: there are different dormitories, but only one is close to the factory. Yours, unfortunately, is far away. You stay with 8 other people in one room. The rent is free, but you have to pay 100 ¥ for facilities in advance.

a1.text: Youâ€™ve had an exhausting day and go to bed.

dorms-morning.text: On your first day you awake before the others and get dressed quietly. Some of them worked the night shift and just went to bed while others have not yet returned. You meet Li Yan outside your room and she tells you to take either the shuttle bus or the motorcycle taxi. They all try to take the bus, but it's up to you as long as you're on time.

a1.text: You to take the bus with everyone else.

a2.text: You to take the taxi and see a bit more of Huizhou.

bus.text: The bus is crowded, but it's fine. You have the opportunity to chat with some of your coworkers and get to know them a bit...

a1.text: You arrive!
You arrive!

telefon.text: You arrive at the factory. Since your grandmother is not feeling well you promised to call her today, however, one of the security guards  sees your phone and takes it from you.

a1.text: You ask him to give it back to you.

a2.text: You just let him go. It's your first day and you don't want to cause trouble.

advicetelefon.text: The security guard ignores you and as he walks away, Li Yan explains to you that phones are not allowed in the factory.

a1.text: Start working

givetelefon.text: You hand him the phone and he lets you pass.

a1.text: Start working

firstday.text: The factory is huge and there are a lot of people around you. You are in charge of drilling into the circuit boards and you are only allowed to take a break every two hours for ten minutes. You are not really able to have chats with your co-workers, since you have to concentrate as to not make any mistakes. After eight hours, your feet and back hurt. Other workers let you know that you are supposed to work at least two more hours of overtime.

a1.text: You feel too tired and go back to the dorms.

a2.text: You fulfill the obligation to stay and work two more hours.

minusdesc.text: You leave early. Your co-workers are surprised and explain to you the attendance award: the average wage they earn is 3000 &yen, but this is including any awards you may earn such as the attendance award. Every time you leave early, 30 &yen are deducted from a possible 120 &yen. If you leave early or come late three times, you forfeit the award entirely.

a1.text: Worried, you go to bed.

minus.text: You leave early even though you know you could use the extra money..

a1.text: You are tired and go to bed.

minusbusy.text: You leave early even though you know you could use the extra money.

a1.text: Worried, you go to bed.

exhausted.text: Your body hurts, you are tired and you really need some rest. When you finally arrive at the dorms you drop into your bed, completely exhausted.

a1.text: You immediately go to sleep.

exhaustedbusy.text: Your body hurts, you are tired and you really need some rest. When you finally arrive at the dorms you drop into your bed, completely exhausted.

a1.text: You immediately go to sleep.

exhaustedquit.text: You need help getting to a hospital since you fell unconscious for a while from your exhaustion. Since the company does not cover your health insurance, you have to pay 950 ¥.

a1.text: Your body hurts, you are tired and you really need some rest. There is no way you could imagine working tomorrow again, so you decide to leave the factory.

quit.text: When you try to resign, they make it extremely difficult for you. They refuse to give you your ID back and after a lot of hassle you leave without getting paid and return to your family. In the end, you barely make it back home with the money you have had left.

workbusy.text: The next day you are back to work. Li Yan tells you it is a busy day since new shipments are coming in and you have to perform accordingly. Your work is exhausting and after working ten hours, you are asked to stay longer.

a1.text: You decide to stay longer.

a2.text: You go home with a bad feeling.

wage.text: After working almost a month, Li Yan tells you your wage will be paid on the 20th of the following month. Since you are still in your probation period, you earn 1300 ¥ and the rest of the attendance award twenty days later.

a1.text: After the probation period your wage will be 1400 ¥ and you will finally be able to send some money back home!

billsstart.text: You have to pay your monthly expenses of 400 ¥.

a1.text: You pay the bills.

drinking.text: Even as you are slowly adjusting to your working conditions, you often feel thirsty, as you are not allowed to drink unless you are on break. If you want to go to the restroom, you need to get a pass, otherwise you may not use the restroom.

a1.text: There is not much you can do about this.

health.text: You talk with co-workers who handle acid to produce the circuit boards you are working on. It seems they were never educated about safety hazards and potential health risks. This makes you question whether or not you really understand what potential risks this job poses for your health.

a1.text: You decide to complain to your superior, since you do not want to take any risks concerning your health.

a2.text: You ignore your gut feeling and get on with your work.

complainhealth.text: You raise your concerns to your supervisor and ask for better safety equipment. He tells you not to worry and to get back to work.

a1.text: You insist on having the matter looked into.

a2.text: You follow his orders and get back to work.

firedhealth.text: The supervisor becomes angry and tells you to mind your own business. He fires you on the spot.

studentsintro.text: You get to know a group of students from three different provinces: Hubei, Hunan and Guizhou. You talk with Yong, one of the students you meet on the way back to the dorms after work. He studies at a technical school and signed a three month contract at a labor dispatch company. They were not trained before starting work, they do not get paid for overhours or subsidy for the night shift. Yong tells you they are freshmen and junior students at college.

a1.text: You are astonished at how hard these young college students have to work.

childworker.text: Another issue that troubles you is that of the child workers. They work extremely hard too. They are also hired by a labor dispatch company and the management tries to make everyone believe that they are of legal age when clearly they are not.

a1.text: You know itâ€™s common to have children working even though it is illegal. There is nothing you can do about it.

studentsadvice.text: After a month, Yong approaches you and asks for your advice. He says the work is too difficult for him and a lot of other students. He spoke with almost 10 students who said they couldn't tolerate the harsh conditions any longer. His supervisor already told him he would not allow students to leave no matter how many quit together.

a1.text: You recommend he should take care of himself and quit.

a2.text: You tell him to be responsible and keep the job - they only have two months left afterall.

studentsunpaid.text: Yong and the others decide to take your advice and quit the next day. The supervisor, however, does not accept their resignations. As a result, they don't get paid their wages or their way back home.

a1.text: You give Yong and two other students money for the bus back home and heavy-heartedly say goodbye to them.

studentsexhausted.text: Yong and the others stay at the factory. They are extremely exhausted in the evenings and you try to cover for them as often as you can. It is pretty exhausting for you.

a1.text: You try to convince them to leave their jobs. They should take care of themselves.

a2.text: You worry about the students but you know they need to make ends meet, so you tell them to just try and get as much work done as possible.

decisionwork.text: Li Yan passes by your dorm after work and you have a chat. She recently switched over to a different department and earns a bit more than before, but tells you that the working conditions are worse. She has no breaks at all and her overtime is much longer than yours. She mentions that the department is hiring and asks you if you were interested in applying.

a1.text: You decide to switch over to her department as well.

a2.text: You decide stay at your department. The extra money is not worth the grueling conditions.

granny.text: Your parents tell you that your grandmother is sick and can not afford her health care. They request that you send money to help pay for her medication. They need 1000 ¥.

a1.text: You send them nothing.

grannydead.text: Your grandmother was not able to afford the medication on her own and got progressively worse. She passed away...

a1.text: There is no time to grieve, you have to get back to work!

workcircle.text: There is never any variation and work feels very repetitive, as you are only standing at the assembly line and drilling the same hole through the circuit board over and over again. As always, you have to decide what to do.

a1.text: You do overtime (2 hours).

a2.text: You leave now and stay at home the next day to fill up your energy.

minuscircle.text: You leave early, even though you know you could use the extra money.

a1.text: You are tired and go to bed early.

minuscircle2.text: You leave early, even though you know you could use the extra money.

a1.text: You are tired and go to bed early.

exhaustedcircle.text: Your body hurts, you are tired and you really need some rest.

a1.text: When you finally arrive at the dorms you are completely exhausted.

exhaustedcircle2.text: Your body hurts, you are tired and you really need some rest. When you finally arrive at the dorms you collapse from exhaustion.

a1.text: When you finally arrive at the dorms you are completely exhausted.

fillenergy.text: You spend the day relaxing and catching up with your family on the phone. By the end of the day you already feel much better.

a1.text: 200 ¥ are deducted from your wage.

fillenergy2.text: You spend the day relaxing and catching up with your family on the phone. By the end of the day you already feel much better.

a1.text: 200 ¥ are deducted from your wage.

firedfill.text: You haven't been to work on three occasions. The company has had enough and fired you. You don't receive this month wage. What will you do next?

helpparents.text: Your parents ask you to help them financially as they no longer obtain the little additional income your grandmother provided.

a1.text: You decide to help and send them 350 ¥.

a2.text: You decide to help and send them 700 ¥.

a3.text: You are not able to send them anything and feel bad about it.

workcircle2.text: Itâ€™s always the same. Standing on the assembly line, attaching this thing to the circuit board. Again and again. As everyday, you have to decide what to do.

a1.text: You do overtime (4 hours).

a2.text: You leave now and stay at home tomorrow to fill up your energy.

a3.text: You go home with a bad feeling.

a1.text: After a month and 20 days you finally receive your paycheck.

bills.text: You have to pay your monthly expenses of %s ¥.

a1.text: You pay the bills.

leavingend.text: You have found a way to sustain your worklife. But at what cost?
